facts.text: Appellant appointed by the Governor-General in July 1942 as Supervisor, Army Ordnance Corps, which was a civil post under the Crown in India.
Appellant appointed as a Labour Supervisor in Extra Temporary Establishment by the COO Ordnance Officer Incharge, Ammunition Depot, Kanpur under authority of Financial Regulations, India, Part 1.

In September and October 1950, appellant served with charge-sheets by Ordnance Officer, Administration, Shakurbasti, Delhi, for making serious false allegations against superior officer Maj. H.S. Dhillon.
Appellant asked for time to submit defence and copies of certain documents.

On May 26, 1951, while inquiry pending, appellant served with order by Ordnance Officer, Administration, Shakurbasti: 'Under instructions received from Army Headquarters you are hereby given one month's notice of discharge with immediate effect, services being no longer required. Your services will be terminated on 25th June, 1951.'
Government of India vide Army Headquarters letter dated May 25, 1951 decided to terminate services by serving one month's notice.
Notice of discharge served by Ordnance Officer, Administration, competent under Army Order No. 1202/1943 read with Financial Regulations.
Appellant filed suit for declaration that order dated May 26, 1951 directing removal from service was wrongful, illegal, void; that he continued in service as Supervisor.
Trial judge held Art. 311 applicable, removal not by appointing authority, decreed suit.

Additional District Judge: Art. 311 not applicable (post connected with defence), terminated under Rule 5 of Civilians in Defence Temporary Services Rules, 1949 by proper authority, allowed appeal, dismissed suit.

Punjab High Court: Salary from Defence estimates, intimately connected with defence, Arts. 309 and 310 applicable but not 311; breach of rules no right to court (citing R. Venkatarao); mala fides not proved, dismissed appeal.
Salary of appellant paid out of estimates of Ministry of Defence.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order dated May 26, 1951 removing the appellant from service was illegal, wrong, void, ultra vires and inoperative.
Whether Article 311 of the Constitution applicable to appellant.
Whether services terminated by proper authority and in compliance with rules.
Whether order vitiated by mala fides.
Whether Section 240 of Government of India Act, 1935 applicable.
Whether Rule 5 of Civilians in Defence Temporary Services Rules, 1949 applicable and complied with.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order passed by officer subordinate to appointing authority (Governor-General); no inquiry as required by Fundamental Rules and Constitution; no adequate opportunity to defend; vitiated by mala fides.
Conditions of service governed by rules under s.241 Government of India Act, 1935, hence entitled to protection of s.240 thereof.
Not afforded opportunity under natural justice.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant held post connected with defence; services terminated under Rule 5 by competent authority (Ordnance Officer under Army Order 1202/1943 and Financial Regulations).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 5 Civilians in Defence Temporary Services Rules, 1949; Army Order No. 1202/1943; Financial Regulations India Part I

court_reasoning.text: Question of Art. 311 applicability concluded by precedents; appellant holds post connected with defence, salary from Defence estimates; Art. 311 not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Engineer in Military Service or similar cannot claim Art. 311 protection.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide s.240 GOI Act applicability as Constitution governs post-1950.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reason to determine s.240 for defence civilian posts.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 5 applicable; notice given by Ordnance Officer under instructions from Army HQ (Ex. P-3, P-2); proper authority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Breach of statutory rules entitles servant to court recourse; High Court's view on Venkatarao overruled.

court_reasoning.text: Mala fides finding by High Court final; cannot reopen.
Natural justice not invocable under general master-servant law absent Art. 311.

holdings.text: Article 311 not applicable to civilian in defence service paid from Defence estimates.
Termination valid under Rule 5 by proper authority with one month's notice.
Breach of statutory service rules enforceable in court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagatrai Mahinchand Ajwani v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 311 not applicable to Engineer in Military Service connected with defence.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.P. Bell v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 311 not applicable to defence connected posts.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. Venkatarao v. Secretary of State
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied for no court recourse on rule breach; not accepted by SC.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Ajodhya Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Breach of statutory service rules entitles recourse to court.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Mysore v. M.R. Bellary
precedents_cited.relevance: Breach of statutory service rules entitles recourse to court.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 311 held inapplicable to defence civilians; 309/310 applicable.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitioner claimed s.240 protection; court did not decide applicability.

statutes_cited.name: Civilians in Defence (Temporary Services) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Services liable to termination by one month's notice; held applicable and complied with.

statutes_cited.name: Army Order No. 1202/1943
statutes_cited.relevance: Competency of Ordnance Officer to serve notice.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; termination of service valid; no protection under Art. 311; Rule 5 complied with; parties to bear own costs in this Court.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs in this Court

key_quotes.text: "Under instructions received from Army Headquarters you are hereby given one months notice of discharge with immediate effect, services being no longer required. Your services will be terminated on 25th June, 1951."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of termination order central to dispute.

key_quotes.text: The question whether the case of the appellant was governed by Art. 311 of the Constitution stands concluded by two decisions of this Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dismisses key petitioner claim based on binding precedents.

key_quotes.text: It has been held that the breach of a statutory rule in relation to the conditions of service would entitle the government servant to have recourse to the court for redress.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Overrules High Court's view on enforceability of rules.
